item.title: Great tutorial on normalizing flows
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: http://akosiorek.github.io/ml/2018/04/03/norm_flows.html This tutorial by Adam Kosiorek is so good that I doubted if normalizing flows are inherently easy to explain. Highly recommended! Advertisements
item.content:encoded:
http://akosiorek.github.io/ml/2018/04/03/norm_flows.html

This tutorial by Adam Kosiorek is so good that I doubted if normalizing flows are inherently easy to explain. Highly recommended!

item.title: SpecAugment
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: SpecAugment is well summarized already in Google AI Blog. What’s interesting for me is seeing people getting surprised by its simplicity – by saying “Why has no one thought of this before?” Seems like many people agree with the augmentation strategies in the paper, namely, i) time warping ii) masking random consecutive mel bins iii) … Continue reading SpecAugment →
item.content:encoded:
SpecAugment is well summarized already in Google AI Blog. What’s interesting for me is seeing people getting surprised by its simplicity – by saying “Why has no one thought of this before?” Seems like many people agree with the augmentation strategies in the paper, namely, i) time warping ii) masking random consecutive mel bins iii) masking random temporal frames.

Time warping is probably the least shocking idea. The idea of using phase vocoder to control the speed has been around for a while. I don’t think I’ve seen the other two.

My understanding of SpecAugment

What does the augmentation do? Well, yes, they change the spectrograms. But in which way? What’s happening exactly? What does the modification mean? First of all, all the effective data augmentation works because they make the training set more diverse within a suitable range.

i)  Time warping works because it increases the diversity of training data, which then covers a wider range of test cases.

ii) Masking random mel bins and time frames works because — from here, I assume that – there are multiple characters or features or shapes or whatever in the spectrogram that are located here and there, and by masking we force the model to (sort of) separate those aspects independently. Say, there’s a phoneme ‘k’, then what makes the sound of ‘k’ would be a combination of different features in, for example, one <400 Hz, one of them maybe 400 Hz < f < 1000 Hz, maybe there are many of them 1k < f < 2k (these are arbitrary numbers). Maybe an easier example would be the formants of vowels. The table below only shows single frequencies of F1, F2, F3 for different phonetic symbols. But they are not absolute, fixed numbers, they should be rather a probabilistic distribution. (Let me skip the explanation of masking time frames.)

So what? That means out of N hints each of which indicates a phoneme (e.g., /uh/), without masking, we’re telling the neural network that if there are all of them, then it’s an /uh/ sound. This means we need all the combinations of those features to completely cover the instances of /uh/ sound. If there are large numbers of features, (if N is large), chances are we don’t have them all. Therefore, this {N dimension vector}-to-{number of phonemes} classifier is hard to train. Data sparsity. Maybe the network even has to extrapolate which it sucks at.

By masking, we’re providing the hints in a more separate way. The network can learn to classify with smaller numbers of features. It also breaks the N-dim feature vectors into something smaller. The N features don’t need to co-exist.

In other words, I guess it addresses the curse of dimensionality to some extent because otherwise, the N-dimensional feature space would be sparse.

More thoughts

Some augmentation methods are not as effective as others. How can we computationally optimize data augment strategies without an exhaustive search?

Well, that’s what Bookmark is for. But well, come on, Bookmark is broken; OH COME ON, it totally missed getting into my habit … Continue reading Jupyter notebook →
item.content:encoded: This blog post already greatly helped me out. Well, probably I would get it again if I google again. Perhaps Google could get me a better one. Well, but what if not? Well, that’s what Bookmark is for. But well, come on, Bookmark is broken; OH COME ON, it totally missed getting into my habit — my psycho-physiological-neural-somewhat_arbitrary brain doesn’t work like that. What would be even worse is if I forget I wrote this. Anyway, to play nice and safe with Jupyter notebook/pip/conda, you might wanna read it.

item.title: Machine Learning for Creativity and Design Workshop (NeurIPS2018), and +@
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: Following their first workshop last year, there was the second ML4 Creativity and Design workshop on 8th Dec 2018 at Neurips2018 (=one of the biggest machine learning conferences), Montreal (=one of the coldest area I’ve ever been). It was great! And even greater for those who are interested in music. I missed the last year’s one but seems … Continue reading Machine Learning for Creativity and Design Workshop (NeurIPS2018), and +@ →
item.content:encoded:
Following their first workshop last year, there was the second ML4 Creativity and Design workshop on 8th Dec 2018 at Neurips2018 (=one of the biggest machine learning conferences), Montreal (=one of the coldest area I’ve ever been). It was great! And even greater for those who are interested in music. I missed the last year’s one but seems like there were more musical stuff this year than before. Here’s my summary for the workshop, a non-exhaustive and mostly musical one, but please treat yourself with other papers too. Ok, here we go.

1. Music-related works

  • “Performing structured improvisations with pre-existing generative musical models”
    • with an intriguing demonstration, which is, hm hm,… live coding music! Why? Because his work is about using trained models realtime.
    • By Pablo Samuel Castro at Google Brain

here’s the second half. wut, can’t tell which is by machine or human? #TuringTestBusted pic.twitter.com/wWcy1gZnZf

— Keunwoo Choi (@keunwoochoi) December 8, 2018

  • “Legend of Wrong Mountain: Full generation of traditional Chinese opera using multiple machine learning algorithms”
    • is such a complete work in a sense that combines LSTM, pix2pix, pix2pixHD, (perhaps other) RNNs, Markov chain, OpoenPose and Detection, etc… to generate music/script/visual, i.e. full.
    • By Lingdong Huang et al. from Carnegie Mellon University
    • Look at this system overview!

  • “Neural wavetable: a playable wavetable synthesizer using neural networks”
    • By Lamtharn Hantrakul and Li-Chia Yang (Google Brain residency and Georgia Tech)
    • To generate an wavetable, which is a (data)base for a certain type of synthesizer (wavetable synthesizer, obviously), they used WaveNet + AutoEncoder so that by controlling the latent space (hidden representation of AutoEncoder) the waveforms of the table can be manipulated continuously.

 

  • “Learning a latent space of multitrack measures” (Magenta blog post)
    • By Ian Simon et al. (from Magenta, Google Brain)
    • It’s an extension of MusicVAE to 8-channel multi-tracks. First, MusicVAE is a VAE-based single-track music generator; that outputs a monophonic melody or a drum track as below – one latent representation (z), applied to the bars of a track globally.

 

  • (continued)
    • Compared to MusicVAE, multitrack VAE is..
      • still with a global z over time, but this time z has multitrack information encoded
      • and with chord conditioned for each bar.

  • “Music theory inspired policy gradient method for piano music transcription”
    • By Jucheng Li et al. (CMU, Stanford, Bosch)
    • Train a Reinforcement Learning-based transcriber with some constraints based on the properties of music and music signal, which are not really described in detail in the paper, but yes I took some pictures! See below.

 

  • “Combining learned lyrical structures and vocabulary for Improved lyric generation”
    • Pablo Samuel Castro and Maria Attarian (Google Brain and Google)
    • to generate lyrics by modelling the grammar of lyric and getting large vocabulary from somewhere else (book)
    • I also thought of something similar as a solution for music captioning where you can extract music tags while sentence templets can be provided from some other sources.

  • “Transformer-NADE for piano performances”
    • by Curtis Hawthorne et al. (Google Magenta)
    • proposed to use NADE (neural autoregressive distribution estimator) to predict the following note and the dimension is an element of note tuple — the elements are properties of note (onset timing, duration, ..).
    • FYI “Transformer” is a purely attention-based sequence-to-sequence model, originally proposed for language translation, recently used for symbolic music generation

  • “Generating images from audio”
    • By Chih Wen Lin and Ting-Wei Su
    • GAN for audio signal-to-image
    • AudioSet (youtube videos) were used during training
  • “VirtuosoNet: A hierarchical attention RNN for generating expressive piano performance from music score”
    • By Dasaem Jeong, Taegyun Kwon, Juhan Nam (KAIST, S Korea)
      • Btw they’re doing great in Maclab at KAIST, please do checkout
    • Input: MusicXML (symbolic score with all the expressions like allegro, forte, crescendo, etc)
    • then additional, global conditioning like “tempo and dynamics” (according to the paper)
    • Output: Midi file with ‘expressions’ added
    • Check out the demo below! It’s pretty cool

 

  • Piano Ginie
    • The coolest ISMIR 2018 demo has come back to NeurIPS!
    • Magenta Demo page

 

2. Some others

  • “Visualizing Music Transformer”
    • by Anna Huang et al. (Google Magenta)
    • It’s from a simultaneous workshop, “Interpretability and robustness in audio speech, and language“
    • Probably one another nice thing about purely attention-based system is that they’re easy to visualise? That’s what Anna did in this work, which would be a nice supplementary to her and her co-workers’ music transformer.
  • “The challenge of realistic music generation: modelling raw audio at scale”
    • By Sander Dieleman et al. (Deepmind)
    • a full conference paper!
    • to add argmax on the top of autoencoder — for longer signal at bigger scale, a harder problem at a stronger conference
  • “Artistic Influence GAN”
    • by Eric Chu, MIT Media Lab
    • “What if Banksy had met Jackson Pollock during his formative years, or if David Hockney had missed out on the Tate Gallery’s famous 1960 Picasso exhibition?”
    • Similar to one thing that I’ve always thought about — to simulate the history of music, maybe with RL though.

3. An awesome talk

  • Michael Levin’s Keynote titled “What bodies think about: Bioelectric computation outside the nervous system, primitive cognition, and synthetic morphology” totally blew many’s minds, I think it could be one that excited the NeurIPS 2018 participants the most — and you don’t need to be a deep learning research to get impressed.

4. Neither musical or talk (i.e. the usual NeurIPS stuff)

  • Sparse attentive backtracking: Temporal credit assignment through reminding
  • How does batch normalization help optimization? (blog post)
    • because, is there any darker and more popular black box than batch norm?

So far (2 days gone), this is my favorite #NeurIPS18 paper. I just love the paper that tells me why it works. It also showed that the popular previous belief "internal covariate shift" has little to do with batch norm's success. Ah!
3-min video: https://t.co/EbcCRDzyAu pic.twitter.com/8eUUWI9G6u

— Aerin Kim (@aerinykim) December 5, 2018

  • Best GAN ever

The student-advisor adversarial idea generator architecture (@dribnet) pic.twitter.com/NQQWB5tBk6

— Mark O. Riedl @NeurIPS (@mark_riedl) December 8, 2018

  • A tutorial on data visualisation
  • Visualizing the loss landscape of neural nets

This work is so impressive and so useful. There was a lot of misplaced skepticism about the importance of sharp minima last year, but this work shows that when you properly normalize you can see what's going on. See the paper for details https://t.co/VV4x49VBU2 https://t.co/CabTgaz4P8

— Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward) December 5, 2018

  • VAE + GAN

IntroVAE: Introspective Variational Autoencoders for Photographic Image Synthesis. They propose a clever way to combine VAE+GAN by reusing the encoder of the VAE as the discriminator, allowing VAE to generate hi-res images. Found this gem at #NeurIPS2018. https://t.co/WQl4DdLyyk pic.twitter.com/hrOpPsJOwT

— hardmaru (@hardmaru) December 4, 2018

Ok this is it. Thanks for the great works everyone!

item.title: Pseudo CQT on Pytorch
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: Here’s a gist for Pseudo CQT on Pytorch   Guess I’ll be working on something like Kapre-but-Pytorch. Torchaudio was a good start but aren’t we deserve something better?
item.content:encoded:
Here’s a gist for Pseudo CQT on Pytorch

 

Guess I’ll be working on something like Kapre-but-Pytorch. Torchaudio was a good start but aren’t we deserve something better?

item.title: ICLR 2019 submissions
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: It’s nice to see some good music-related submissions in ICLR 2019. Many are about timbre transfer as a part of music style transfer, which is great as now many are clarifying the scope of the problem rather than “style transfer” where the “style” is retrospectively defined by whatever happened in their neural networks. Some of … Continue reading ICLR 2019 submissions →
item.content:encoded:
It’s nice to see some good music-related submissions in ICLR 2019. Many are about timbre transfer as a part of music style transfer, which is great as now many are clarifying the scope of the problem rather than “style transfer” where the “style” is retrospectively defined by whatever happened in their neural networks.

Some of my comments are as below:

  1. “Autoencoder-based music translation”
  2. “TimbreTron: A WaveNet(CycleGAN(CQT(Audio))) Pipeline for musical timbre transfer”

Please go check out the submissions! → 11 results found for “music”

item.title: ISMIR 2018 tutorials + etc
item.dc:creator: keunwoochoi
item.description: Here’s a bunch of links on ISMIR 2018 tutorials T1. Open Source and Reproducible MIR Research | github repo T2. Computational approaches for analysis of non-western music traditions | materials T3. Statistical analysis of results in MIR: Why and how | slides T4. Music separation with DNNs: Making it work | materials T5. Deep learning for MIR | github repo T6. Fundamental frequency estimation in music | slides 1, 2, 3 T7. Optical music recognition for … Continue reading ISMIR 2018 tutorials + etc →
item.content:encoded:
Here’s a bunch of links on ISMIR 2018 tutorials

T1. Open Source and Reproducible MIR Research | github repo

T2. Computational approaches for analysis of non-western music traditions | materials

T3. Statistical analysis of results in MIR: Why and how | slides

T4. Music separation with DNNs: Making it work | materials

T5. Deep learning for MIR | github repo

T6. Fundamental frequency estimation in music | slides 1, 2, 3

T7. Optical music recognition for dummies | (todo)

T8. Overview and new challenges of music recommendation research in 2018 | slides

 

Also please check out ISMIR 2018 YouTube channel!
